p: COVID-19 presents stark evidence of the increasingly damaging relationship between human society and the biosphere; the emergence and spread of the pandemic is related to habitat destruction, urbanization, live animal trade and intensive livestock farming amongst other factors (Barouki et al. 2021). Global over-consumption is placing stress on Earth’s natural life-support systems as never before. World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF 2018) have reported a 60% decline in overall populations of mammals, reptiles, fish, birds and amphibians in the 4 decades following 1970. Nevertheless, large swathes of the global population continue to experience the deprivations of poverty and resource scarcity (UNDP 2019). For example, the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP 2019, p 1) report that “17% of children born in 2000 in so-called low human development countries will have died before age 20, compared with a figure of 1% in very high human development countries”.
